alt_statements.statement: I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who became a citizen and works hard while raising kids alone, it doesn’t feel right that some states get more power than others and our voices can be watered down. A direct popular vote would make politicians pay attention to all communities, including immigrants and working-class families like mine.

As a voter and a mom, I’d like my kids to grow up in a country where every person’s vote truly counts the same, no matter what state they live in, so I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. The current system makes a handful of swing states far too important and can put someone in the White House who didn’t win the most votes overall, which just feels unfair and undemocratic.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, but modestly updated rather than scrapped. A pure popular vote would shift all attention to a few big urban centers and ignore states like mine, but I’d support reforms such as allocating electors by congressional district (like Maine and Nebraska) and tightening rules to ensure transparency and integrity in how votes are counted and certified.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some modest reforms rather than being scrapped. It protects smaller and more rural states like Oklahoma from being totally overshadowed by big cities, but we could look at ideas like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening up rules around faithless electors to make the system feel fairer and more accountable.

As someone who believes in our constitutional framework and the importance of states’ rights, I don’t think the Electoral College should be abolished, but I’m open to modest reforms that keep its basic structure. I could support changes that make electors bound to their state’s popular vote and perhaps allocate electoral votes by congressional district instead of winner-take-all, so that rural and suburban communities like mine still have a real voice while individual votes are better reflected.

Given my background in higher education, I tend to favor reforms that make our democracy more responsive and easier for my students and children to understand as fundamentally fair. I would support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, or at least adopting proportional allocation of electoral votes within states, so that every ballot is weighted equally regardless of where someone lives. This would encourage candidates to campaign across the whole country rather than focusing on a handful of swing states, and it aligns better with my commitment to democratic inclusion and political equality.

As someone who became an American by choice and works every day alongside people from all walks of life, I believe the president should be chosen by a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in a big city or a rural town. The Electoral College makes some votes effectively matter more than others and encourages campaigns to ignore states they see as “safe,” which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or my faith’s belief in the equal worth of every person. I would support either abolishing it in favor of a national popular vote or, at minimum, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to align the outcome more closely with the will of the people.

As someone who believes in our constitutional system and tends to be cautious about sweeping changes, I don’t think the Electoral College should be scrapped outright, but it could be reformed. I’d support changes that ensure rural and smaller states like many in the heartland keep a real voice, while also making the process more reflective of the popular vote—such as moving to a district-based allocation of electors rather than winner-take-all at the state level.

As someone who’s spent a career in finance, I’m acutely aware of how distortions in a system can skew outcomes, and the Electoral College is a prime example: it gives outsized power to a handful of swing states and undermines the basic democratic principle of one person, one vote. I’d like to see it replaced with a national popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting, so every ballot is weighed equally and candidates have to appeal to the whole country, not just a narrow slice of it.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller and rural states like mine in Oregon aren’t completely drowned out by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d support reforms that keep the basic system but make it fairer, like adopting the Maine and Nebraska model everywhere so electoral votes are split by congressional district instead of winner-take-all.

At my age, I still believe the Electoral College serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and rural communities like the one I grew up in. I would support modest reforms—such as improving transparency in how electors are chosen or considering proportional allocation within states—but I do not favor abolishing the system in favor of a pure popular vote.

As a conservative and a Republican, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the influence of smaller states and keeps our elections from being dominated solely by big cities and coastal populations. That said, I’d support reforms that increase transparency and public confidence—like clearer, uniform rules for how states handle recounts and disputes—without overturning the basic structure that has helped maintain stability in our system.

As someone who spends his life performing for all kinds of people across the country, I’ve seen firsthand how every voice deserves to carry equal weight, and our current Electoral College system doesn’t always honor that. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote so that the president is simply the person who wins the most votes, no matter where they come from. Short of that, I’d back reforms like proportional allocation of electors and ranked-choice voting, so elections better reflect the actual will of the people rather than a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and rural states like Alabama aren’t steamrolled by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to some reforms—like states adopting a system similar to Maine and Nebraska that awards some electoral votes by congressional district—so people feel their vote matters even if their state usually leans one way. Overall, I don’t want to scrap the system, just update it so it’s fairer while still protecting the voice of less populated states.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count equally no matter what state they’re in. It feels wrong that a candidate can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it makes a lot of people feel like their voices don’t matter, especially in “safe” states. As someone who cares about fairness and reducing unnecessary conflict, a simple one-person-one-vote system seems more honest and democratic.

I think we should keep the Electoral College but modernize it instead of scrapping it. It helps make sure smaller states like mine in Nebraska still have a voice, instead of everything being decided by huge cities on the coasts. But I’m cool with ideas like splitting electoral votes by district, like Nebraska already does, so people’s votes feel more direct without losing the balance between states.

At my age, I’ve seen the country go through a lot, and I still believe the Electoral College plays an important role in protecting smaller states and preventing big cities from completely deciding our elections. I don’t think it should be abolished, but it could be improved by tightening rules so that states can’t just change how they allocate electors for partisan advantage. The Constitution’s structure has served us well for a long time, and any reform should respect that design instead of chasing every political trend.

As someone who swore an oath to uphold the Constitution, I respect the history behind the Electoral College, but I think it’s out of step with modern democracy. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors so that every vote, whether it’s in Massachusetts or a swing state, counts equally. That would make the system fairer, increase turnout, and reduce the feeling that a handful of states decide the presidency for everyone else.

The Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states, prevents candidates from only focusing on big coastal cities, and reinforces the federal nature of our system. That said, I’d support some targeted reforms—like tightening rules on electors so they must vote according to their state’s results, and improving transparency in how votes are counted—to maintain public trust without throwing out a system that has provided stability for over two centuries.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to know the Electoral College doesn’t always reflect the will of the people, and that just doesn’t sit right with me as someone who believes every voice should count equally, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least require states to allocate their electors proportionally so that every vote truly matters. As a Christian, I believe fairness and honesty are moral issues, and a system that can let the loser of the popular vote win the presidency feels out of step with those values.

As a naturalized citizen, I respect the Electoral College because it forces candidates to appeal to a broad range of states, not just the biggest cities, and that protects voices in smaller or less-populated places like where many immigrant families build their lives. I would support modest reforms—such as increasing transparency in how electors are chosen or encouraging states to adopt a district-based allocation like Maine and Nebraska—but I do not support abolishing the Electoral College in favor of a national popular vote, which I believe would centralize power and deepen division.

I don’t see much good in throwing out the Electoral College entirely; this country’s built on a balance between the states, not just big cities and the coasts. I’d be open to some tweaks, like making states award their electors by congressional district or tightening up how votes are counted and verified, but I still want the system to protect smaller, rural states like mine from being steamrolled.

At my age, having taught American history for decades, I’ve come to see the Electoral College as an outdated compromise that often undermines the principle of one person, one vote. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at least reforming it so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally within each state, to better reflect the will of the people. From a democratic and Catholic social teaching perspective—emphasizing human dignity and the common good—it troubles me that some citizens’ votes effectively count more than others simply because of where they live.

Given how much I care about community and making sure everyone has a real voice, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful and can put someone in the White House who didn’t actually win the most votes, which doesn’t feel democratic or fair. As a Democrat and a liberal, I want reforms that expand participation and representation, not ones that distort it.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot really counts the same, whether they live in Texas like me or in a small swing state. A popular vote would push candidates to focus on everyone’s needs, not just the people in “important” states, and that lines up more with the democratic and Christian values of equality and fairness that I believe in.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you live in Ohio like me or in a big coastal state. If a full replacement isn’t possible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us in that direction.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. A popular vote system feels fairer to me, especially for people like my family who moved here and worked hard to become citizens so our voices would matter. At the same time, I’d want strong rules to protect smaller communities from being ignored, like maybe keeping some limits on how much any one state can control the outcome.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College no longer serves us well and should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same, no matter where they live. I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or a constitutional amendment to ensure that the president is chosen directly by the people, reflecting the democratic ideals we claim to uphold.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but maybe updated a bit so people feel their vote counts more, like using the district-based system they have in Maine and Nebraska. I think the person who gets the most votes from everybody in the whole country should be the president, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote in class and we count everyone’s vote the same. I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but it seems a little weird that the person with fewer votes can still be president. As a conservative and a naturalized citizen, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modestly reformed, not abolished. As a Democrat and a believer in one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every American’s ballot counts equally, whether you live in Ohio like me or in a so‑called “swing state.” It doesn’t make sense that a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the presidency, and that system leaves a lot of people feeling ignored and stressed about whether their voice matters. As a naturalized citizen who’s built a life and career arguing about fairness and due process, I find the Electoral College structurally skewed and at odds with the democratic principle of “one person, one vote.” I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote—ideally with ranked-choice voting—to ensure every ballot carries equal weight regardless of state lines and to reduce the disproportionate influence of a handful of swing states. This reform would bring our presidential elections more in line with the feminist and liberal values I care about: equal political voice, transparency, and genuine accountability to the majority of voters.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, because it protects smaller and rural states like West Virginia from being completely ignored by big cities. As someone who believes in equality and wants my kids to feel like their voices truly matter, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As someone who believes in fairness and every voice counting equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same no matter what state they live in. I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. Maybe we could have a system where the popular vote decides the winner, so the president is the person most Americans actually chose.

I think the president should be chosen by whoever gets the most votes from all the people, because that feels the most fair and fair things are really important to me. If we kept it, I’d want it to be changed so every person’s vote matters the same no matter what state they live in.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed but not completely scrapped. As someone raising kids and trying to make ends meet, I want my vote in Oregon to matter more, but I also don’t want rural and smaller states to be ignored.

I think the Electoral College should stay, but it could use a few tweaks to make people feel their vote matters more. A straight popular vote would let big cities decide everything, and folks like me in manufacturing towns would get ignored, but I’m open to things like allocating electors by district or tightening rules so states can’t just change how they run elections on a whim.

As someone who believes in both fairness and practicality, I think we should move toward a national popular vote for president, either by constitutional amendment or through something like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact. In my kitchen, every plate I send out counts equally, and I feel the same way about votes—every citizen’s ballot, whether they live in a big city or rural town, should carry the same weight. The current Electoral College system encourages candidates to focus mostly on a handful of swing states, which leaves a lot of Americans effectively on the sidelines and doesn’t reflect the diversity and complexity of the country I see in the food world every day. As someone who believes in our Constitution and the importance of federalism, I don’t think the Electoral College should be abolished, but I do believe it can be improved. I’d support reforms such as allocating electors by congressional district, or requiring states to follow clearer, uniform rules, so that rural and smaller states still have a voice while the outcome better reflects the will of the people.

I’ve spent a lifetime looking at old maps and watching how our country has grown, and it doesn’t sit right with me that a few swing states can outweigh millions of votes elsewhere. As someone who chose to become an American and drives people from every background around the city, I think the president should be elected by a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. As a naturalized citizen who came from a country with a more straightforward national vote, I find the Electoral College outdated and at odds with the democratic principle that every vote should count equally. I don’t think we should throw out the Electoral College completely, but I do think it could use some updating. As a civics-minded teacher and a mom, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in Utah or New York. As a naturalized citizen who worked hard to build a life here, it bothers me that the Electoral College can effectively make some people’s votes count more than others, especially in states with large Black and immigrant communities that are taken for granted. As someone who believes in fairness and evidence-based policy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in Texas or Vermont. As a conservative and a firm believer in our Constitution, I think the Electoral College should be preserved because it protects the voice of smaller and less-populated states like my home state of Indiana. I’d like to see the Electoral College modernized, not scrapped outright. I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept, because it makes sure smaller states like mine still matter and aren’t totally drowned out by big cities on the coasts. Given how much I care about fairness and making sure everyone’s voice is heard, I support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether you live in Montana or New York. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, strengthen our democracy, and align with the idea that “one person, one vote” really means the same thing for all of us.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to feel that the Electoral College just doesn’t reflect the will of the people the way it should. As a naturalized citizen, I value the stability and balance the Electoral College provides, especially in making sure smaller and less populated states still matter in national elections. I don’t totally trust the Electoral College the way it is now, because it feels like some people’s votes count more depending on what state they’re in. I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states like my own Oregon, but it could use some careful reform. I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some tightening around things like faithless electors so they’re bound to the people’s vote in their state. As someone who travels and performs across the country, I’m constantly reminded that every voice deserves the same weight, whether it’s in New York or a small town in the Midwest. I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot should count the same no matter what state they live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally instead of winner-take-all. That would make candidates pay attention to all communities—including Latino and working families like mine—instead of just a handful of swing states.

As someone who believes in democracy and comes from a community that’s seen its voice diluted before, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful, and that doesn’t sit right with my values of fairness and representation. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to all kinds of communities—urban, rural, Black, white, and everything in between—instead of just chasing electoral math.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who cares about social justice, it doesn’t feel fair that a few swing states get so much power while a lot of people’s votes end up not really mattering. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more diverse communities, including people like me, instead of just focusing on certain states.

Given how much I value evidence and fairness in my work, I’m deeply uncomfortable with a system where someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a direct national popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting, so every ballot counts equally no matter where you live. That seems more consistent with a modern democracy and would reduce the outsized influence of a handful of swing states.

The Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. As someone who cares about social justice and lives simply but pays close attention to politics, I see the current system as structurally unfair, amplifying some voices while muting others—especially marginalized communities. A popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and make it harder for politicians to ignore those of us without money, status, or swing-state zip codes.

Given my background as a naturalized citizen and a conservative, I believe the Electoral College plays an important role in protecting the voice of smaller and less populous states, preventing a few big cities from dominating national elections. That said, I could support modest reforms such as allocating electors by congressional district, as Maine and Nebraska do, to more closely reflect the popular vote within each state without abandoning the federalist structure the Founders intended.

At my age, I’ve seen the Electoral College protect smaller and rural states from being completely ignored by big coastal cities, and I still think that balance matters. I’d keep the Electoral College, but I’d like to see reforms such as states adopting proportional allocation of electoral votes instead of winner-take-all, so people in the minority party in each state still feel their votes count. That way we preserve the voice of diverse regions while making the system fairer and more responsive to the popular will.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed, not scrapped entirely. A national popular vote sounds fair on the surface, but I worry that big cities would end up deciding everything and places like North Carolina wouldn’t matter. I’d rather see changes like proportional allocation of electoral votes or ranked-choice voting in each state so people’s votes count more directly while still keeping some balance between states.

I don’t really understand all the details about the Electoral College, but I think everyone’s vote should count the same no matter where they live, kind of like how everyone on a team gets one turn. It feels fair if the person who the most people pick becomes the leader, like choosing a class helper by everyone raising their hands. That way, people in every place—big cities and small towns—know their voices matter.

Coming from a small-town Tennessee background and caring a lot about fairness and representation, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you’re in. The current system makes a handful of swing states way too powerful and sidelines issues I care about, like climate action and sustainable policy, because candidates chase Electoral College math instead of the actual majority of voters.

As a Catholic and a Democrat who cares deeply about fairness and the common good, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. Right now, candidates focus on a handful of swing states and ignore so many voices, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of justice or my belief in the dignity of every person. I’d support reforms that either abolish the Electoral College or bind it more tightly to the national popular vote, so the winner truly reflects the will of the majority.

As someone who’s spent her career thinking about systems and impacts, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter where you live. The current system makes some states matter far more than others and discourages participation, which undermines both fairness and democracy. A well-designed popular vote system—with strong national voting standards, protections against voter suppression, and secure election administration—would better reflect the will of the people.

Given how much I work with systems and efficiency, the Electoral College feels like a legacy architecture that no longer scales for a modern democracy. I’d support moving to a national popular vote—ideally with ranked-choice voting—so that every ballot is weighted equally and candidates have to campaign everywhere, not just in swing states. That kind of reform would align better with democratic principles while leveraging data and technology to administer elections securely and transparently.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I still think the Electoral College serves an important purpose in forcing candidates to pay attention to smaller and less populous states, not just the big coastal cities. That said, I’d support some modest reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around “faithless electors”—to make the system feel a bit fairer and more transparent, without scrapping a structure that has generally kept the country stable for over two centuries.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modernized, not scrapped. It forces candidates to build broad, nationwide coalitions instead of just appealing to a few big coastal cities, which helps protect the voice of states like Ohio. That said, I’d support practical reforms like improving how electors are chosen, increasing transparency, and exploring state-level changes such as proportional allocation of electors to better reflect voters’ choices without undermining the constitutional balance.

I think the Electoral College should basically stay in place, because it protects the voice of smaller and more rural states like Utah so we’re not completely drowned out by big cities on the coasts. If there are reforms, I’d support things like tightening voter ID laws and improving how votes are counted and reported, rather than scrapping the whole system.

I think it would be more fair if the president was chosen by whoever gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country, kind of like how we pick class reps by counting every vote. The Electoral College seems confusing and makes some people’s votes in smaller states matter more, and that doesn’t feel equal. Since my parents teach me that everyone should have the same voice and that being fair is important, I’d want a system where every vote counts the same no matter where you live.

I don’t think the Electoral College should be scrapped, but I do believe it could use some tightening up. It protects smaller states like mine from being steamrolled by big coastal cities, and that balance matters, but we should push states to stick with winner-take-all and avoid games like changing the rules midstream or letting rogue electors ignore voters. If anything, reforms should focus on making elections more secure, transparent, and consistent across states—not on turning the presidency into a pure popular vote contest.

I believe the Electoral College should be kept, but updated so people feel their votes really count. As a conservative and a Catholic, I worry that going to a straight popular vote would let big coastal cities drown out the voices of smaller, more rural states like Missouri. We could consider reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or making the process more transparent, but we shouldn’t throw out a system that protects state representation and stability.

The Electoral College needs serious reform, if not outright replacement, because it lets a handful of swing states decide elections instead of treating every citizen’s vote equally. I’d support a national popular vote with strong safeguards for election integrity, federalism, and ballot access, so smaller states and minority viewpoints aren’t steamrolled by big-city majorities. A system like ranked-choice voting at the national level could also open the door for viable independent and third-party candidates, which fits my belief in individual choice over rigid party machines. Whatever we do, it should increase accountability to actual voters, not to party strategists gaming the map.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in Texas or anywhere else. As someone working hard, raising kids, and not having a lot of extra time or power, it matters to me that the winner is simply whoever gets the most votes from the people. I’m not tied to either party, and I don’t like the idea that a few swing states get all the attention while the rest of us feel ignored.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but updated so that it better reflects the will of voters in each state. For example, more states could adopt a system like Maine and Nebraska, where electoral votes are partly based on congressional districts, so rural and small-town voices like ours aren’t drowned out by big cities, but every vote still feels like it matters.

Given how closely divided our country is and how much I value every person’s voice, I think we should move to a national popular vote for president so that the candidate who gets the most votes actually wins. The Electoral College might have made sense in the 18th century, but today it distorts campaigns around a handful of swing states and makes many voters—rural or urban—feel like their vote doesn’t matter. I’d support either a constitutional amendment to replace it outright or, at the very least, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact that push us toward “one person, one vote” in practice.
